I can find no evidence to suggest any of the 15 nations that recognize Taiwan is considering changing its status.  All 15 have re-affirmed their commitment to Taiwan sometime in the last year, either through public statements by heads of state and/or expansion of trade alliances.  Moreover, China’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and treatment of Hong Kong in July 2020 strengthened Taiwan’s global diplomatic position.  Despite China’s offers of foreign direct investment and interest free loans, Haiti rebuffed China’s response to the Hong Kong protests then accepted a $150M aid package from Taiwan. Countries which have recently changed diplomatic allegiance from Taiwan to China did so primarily for economic reasons.  For example, China is the Solomon Islands’ largest export recipient and the Dominican Republic ceased recognizing Taiwan shortly before joining China’s Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) in 2019.  Taiwan’s remaining diplomatic allies are less susceptible to China’s economic influence.  None are party to the BRI and many are large trade partners with the U.S. and Taiwan.  I found no information to suggest any of the remaining 15 nations is imminently expanding trade agreements with China. A new U.S. Presidential Administration may shift the geopolitical landscape in favor of China, but not before 28 February.  The Trump Administration was extremely pro-Taiwan and often antagonistic of China.  The Biden Administration has used softer rhetoric, which may suggest China can be more aggressive in its efforts to isolate Taiwan diplomatically.  However, in January 2020, then-candidate Joseph Biden publicly congratulated the President of Taiwan on her election victory, stating: “The United States should continue strengthening our ties with Taiwan and other like-minded democracies.”  This suggests we should not anticipate a drastic or immediate change of U.S. position on Taiwan. Absent any information to the contrary, I see no reason to deviate from the crowd forecast of 4%.

As of 3 January, only 14 countries of 193 in the United Nations officially recognize Taiwan: Belize, Eswatini, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Nicaragua, Palau, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and Tuvalu. The Vatican/Holy See also recognizes Taiwan. There is precedence for 1 of these 14 nations to cease formally recognizing Taiwan.  In the past three years, there have been multiple instances whereby countries cease to recognize Tapai and acknowledge Beijing as the ruling government of China.  Two countries ceased to recognize Taiwan in Sep 2019 (the Solomon Islands and Kiribati), three in 2018 (El Salvador, Burkino Faso, and the Dominican Republic), and one in 2017 (Panama).   Following the 2020 Presidential election in Taiwan, Nicaragua and Paraguay did not send congratulatory messages to the newly elected president (the vice-president of each nation sent the congratulations instead).  This sparked concern that relations had deteriorated, which could be a sign that either nation might cease to recognize Taiwan.  However, this did not occur. Since at least one country switched allegiances in each of the last three years, (a 100% occurrence rate), it would make sense that there is a 8.3% chance that it could occur in any month this year.  So over the next two months, at most it would be a 16.6% chance.  Also worth considering in this case, does a country switching allegiances make it more likely or less likely that others would follow (bandwagon theory or staunch hold-out)? This principle has been used to 'persuade' countries wanting to establish diplomatic relations with PRC to break ties with Taiwan (ROC). See https://bbc.in/3b0ZgXA. Clearly, PRC's continued economic strength, the distribution of largesse (with ties attached) and growing integration in global supply chains has give PRC the leverage to continue enforcing the One China principle. As I have previously questioned, this leads to the core of the GJP question; i.e. for a 'country to formally cease to recognize Taiwan', one has to assume that this would be a country that has formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan. The list of countries with full diplomatic ties (https://bit.ly/3oa0R0X) seems to be relatively limited and in the current climate, unlikely to be under pressure from PRC to formally break this ties.

14 countries still recognize the ROC. In a period of 20 years, from 2001-2020, 10 countries switched their diplomatic recognition from the ROC to the PRC, (10 of 24 possible, or 42%). Extrapolating forward, 42% of the remaining 14 countries would be approximately 6 that might switch in the next 20 years. However, it is reasonable to assume that the countries that have held out to this day are more staunch in their support of Taiwan. Thus, I’m estimating down to 5 countries switching from 2021-2040. (Assuming of course, the status quo that the ROC is not taken over by the PRC) At this rate, over the next 20 years it is one county switching every 4 years, which is equivalent to 1 country every 48 months. The forecast period is from 9 Nov to 28 Feb. At the time of this forecast (1 Jan 2021) there are only two months remaining, and takeover of the ROC by the PRC appears unlikely. Since on average it is 48 months for a country to switch by my estimate, the chances are 2/48 = 4.2% of a country ceasing to recognize Taiwan by 28 Feb 2021.

However, over the last 30 years that pace has slowed to .43 states per year.  Since the remaining states have had ample opportunity to switch by now and haven't, I think the base rate is probably closer to .43 than to 1.1.  Accordingly, I'll use .6 states per year as my starting point.  As of today 84 days remain in the forecast window, which is 23 percent of a year.  .6 x .23 = .138 or 13.8% as a reasonable "outside view."  To establish an inside view, you have to look at specifics of the relationships between the 15 states and Taiwan/China.

I'm having a hard time nailing down solid data with regard to base rates when it comes to ceasing to recognize Taiwan. Therefore, I'm going to set that aside for a moment and focus on those that recognize them now. Of the 15 states that still recognize Taiwan, 3, or 20% at one point stopped recognizing them, leading me to believe that they might have a slightly higher likelihood of doing so again, simply because they've already crossed that bridge once.  According to this paper (http://aacs.ccny.cuny.edu/2018conference/Dahmer%20Rich%20%20AACS%20paper%209-20-18.pdf), Taiwan's efforts to hold on to recognition in central America have centered around trade, aid, and investment, as well as involvement in regional intergovernmental organizations. The authors speculate, however, that as ideological incentives decline and PRC economic incentives increase, Taiwan will have to redouble their efforts. I was unable to find significant sourcing regarding more current strategies on the part of Taiwan (the paper was from 2018), but assuming things remained status quo, or perhaps even continued to decline relative to PRC's ability to pump money into the region, I'd suggest that the two Nicaragua, at least, might have a slightly higher probability of jumping off the bandwagon again. With regard to the other two, Nauru and St Lucia, Nauru might be thought to be at risk of defecting, as their neighbors in the Solomon Islands and Kirbati did not to long ago (ref @Foursight's analysis & sourcing), but Nauru also recently pledged their allegiance to Taiwan (again, ref @Foursight's notes).  That leaves St Lucia as the remaining one of the three that has already jumped ship and therefore might be expected to have a higher likelihood of doing so again. The prime minister recently traveled to Taiwan to celebrate its founding (https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3035240/taiwans-allies-dwindle-st-lucia-stands-firm-against-china...and yes, I realize the source, but the Prime Minister traveled, that's an indisputable fact), so that sends a pretty strong signal that St Lucia's on board, at least for the time being. So where does that leave us? I'd say that BRI has a strong pull for some nations - it's tough to turn down investment when PRC comes calling. I estimate that the PRC's redoubling of effort with regard to this initiative raises the probability somewhat in the near-term, at least relative to the longer term base rate we might calculate.  In addition to that, it appears to me that @Awisdomofwombats seems to have come up with some information regarding the ceasing of recognition. He or she has come up with a rate of about 1 a year and, given the amount of time left until 1 Mar, estimates the probability at about 28%. I like that as a starting rate, but I have a sneaking suspicion that there is something to be said for an exponential growth re "strength of bond" as the number of countries dwindles. In other words, the ones that are easier to peel off have been peeled off, and each one left requires an increased amount of effort on the part of PRC to get them to come over to their side.  To this point, most of the considerations moving me away from the base rate have trended downward, toward a lower likelihood. The one thing I think might offer a slight tip in the direction of greater probability is uncertainty regarding the US political situation. While on one hand the Trump administration has seemed to (at times) signal a hard line against the PRC, at least with regard to trade, the foreign policy has been somewhat schizophrenic, leading me to believe that the Chinese might consider the Biden administration on its surface a less desirable future (and therefore take advantage of these next 6 weeks to apply increased pressure and try to move some more countries in their direction), but I also think that the Chinese might actually prefer what they perceive to be an increasingly stable (if perhaps less favorable) position once a Biden administration is in place. SO!!! Starting at 28% and moving mostly downward but with a slight bump upward for the increased opportunity offered by the current window of political uncertainty vis-a-vis US domestic politics, I'm going to set the line at 15%. I'll keep an eye out and see which direction things move in the near future.

In the last 72 years, approximately 114 changes in recognition from the ROC to PRC have occurred with tight grouping in the two 5 year periods after the Communist victory in the civil war in 1949 and after Nixon's visit to China in 1972. This gives a  rate of 1 change of recognition to the PRC per every 7.6 months. The rate over the last 30 years has been 1 change per every 1.30 years. Averaging these two rates gives a change of 1 per every 0.97 years. Therefore, I would estimate that the occurrence of a derecognition event over the period from today to 28 Feb (108 days) is (108/365.24 * 0.9667) = 28.6%. I could not find any particular information (trade deals, coercion, diplomatic exchanges) about the 4 countries (or any of the other 10) listed above that makes me believe compellingly that they are any more or less likely to derecognize the ROC in favor of the PRC than the baseline over the next 108 days, ergo 28.6%. I admit that I would prefer a complex Bayesian decision model to explain this problem, but given the relatively large sample size of derecognitions and the paucity of data on internal interstate negotiations between the PRC and these 14 nations, I see no valid reason to disregard a frequentist approach as specious. The main driver for approaching this problem from a Bayesian modeling standpoint would be if the pool of countries recognizing the ROC dropped below ~10, then individual decision-making and detailed information should become more deterministic of the outcome.
